summary: On February 22, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California entered a final judgment against Party City Corporation and PLCM Group, Inc., alleging that Party City violated the antifraud provisions of Section 1747 of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Los Angeles, Party City and its counsel, Gene J. Stonebarger, agreed to settle the charges without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint.  The settlement also provided for the payment of attorney fees, costs, and incentive awards to Party City's class counsel.  In its final judgment, the court found that the fees and costs were reasonable and reasonable and that party City was entitled to fair compensation based on the reasonable number of hours spent on the litigation.  However, according to the complaint, as a result of the settlement, party City did not qualify for fair compensation because it did not have sufficient evidence to justify the fee award.  Instead, as the complaint alleges, the defendants spent significant time on the case and did not provide any evidence to support their claim.  Party City also failed to provide sufficient documentation to support its claim that it had improperly waived the attorney-client privilege.  As a result, the settlement is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-8221 (January 29, 2013).  The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued an Investor Alert to encourage investors to check the backgrounds of people selling investments using the free and simple search tool onÂ Investor.govÂ to identify whether they are registered professionals.Â The SEC's Complaint alleges that, contrary to the representations made in the Complaint, Parties to a Contract have the right to request and receive an attorney fee as part of their compensation.  Parties to the Contract also have the duty to provide reasonable, not duplicative, information to the court.  To learn more about attorney fees and compensation, see Investor.gov.  Investors can also check the background of anyone selling investments by using the investor.gov website to quickly identify whether there are any conflicts of interest.  Finally, the SEC acknowledges the assistance of the California Office of Financial Regulation, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Office of Inspector General in this matter.
